_comment: Add a new WMD article by creating articles/your-id.wmd and appending an entry here. The 'path' for WMD articles always points to articles/article.html?id=<your-id>.

articles.title: About EduWiki
articles.summary: Learn about EduWiki â€” what it is, what it covers, and how to navigate and use the site.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Introduction to Calculus
articles.summary: Calculus is the mathematical study of continuous change. It has two major branches: differential calculus and integral calculus.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Abstract Algebra
articles.summary: Abstract algebra studies algebraic structures — groups, rings, and fields — by identifying the abstract axioms they satisfy, rather than working with specific numbers.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Real Analysis
articles.summary: Real analysis is the rigorous mathematical study of the real number line and the functions defined on it — the formal foundation underlying calculus.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Mathematics
articles.summary: Mathematics is the science of pattern, structure, quantity, and logical deduction — humanity's most powerful tool for understanding the physical world with precision and rigor.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Geometry
articles.summary: Geometry is the mathematical study of shape, size, and the properties of space — from Euclid's five postulates and Euclidean geometry to the curved spacetime of general relativity.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Pythagorean Theorem
articles.summary: The Pythagorean theorem describes the relationship between the three sides of a right triangle: a² + b² = c².
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Jesus Christ
articles.summary: Jesus Christ is the central figure of Christianity and of Latter-day Saint faith — the Son of God, Savior, and Redeemer of all mankind.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Book of Mormon
articles.summary: The Book of Mormon is a sacred scripture of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, translated by Joseph Smith from golden plates and serving as another testament of Jesus Christ.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Joseph Smith
articles.summary: Joseph Smith Jr. (1805–1844) was the founding prophet of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, translator of the Book of Mormon, and restorer of Christ's gospel.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Ancient Rome
articles.summary: Ancient Rome was one of the most powerful civilizations in world history, whose legal, political, and cultural legacy continues to shape the modern world — and provided the setting for the early Christian church.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Latin
articles.summary: Latin is the classical language of Rome, the foundation of the Romance languages, the language of early Christian scripture, and a cornerstone of Western learning.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Ancient Greek
articles.summary: Ancient Greek is the language of Homer, Plato, and the New Testament — one of history's most influential languages and a key tool for scriptural study.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Old English
articles.summary: Old English (Anglo-Saxon) is the earliest form of the English language, spoken in England from roughly 450–1150 AD, and the mother tongue of Beowulf and early Christian writings.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Augustine of Hippo
articles.summary: Augustine of Hippo (354–430 AD) was one of the most influential theologians in Christian history, whose writings on grace, original sin, and the City of God shaped Western Christianity for over a thousand years.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Thomas Aquinas
articles.summary: Thomas Aquinas (1225–1274) was a Dominican friar and theologian whose Summa Theologica represents the greatest synthesis of Christian faith and Aristotelian philosophy ever attempted. His Five Ways remain among the most discussed arguments for God's existence.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Martin Luther
articles.summary: Martin Luther (1483–1546) was a German monk and reformer whose Ninety-Five Theses sparked the Protestant Reformation — one of the most consequential events in the history of Christianity.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Parley P. Pratt
articles.summary: Parley Parker Pratt (1807–1857) was one of the original Twelve Apostles of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and a prolific writer, missionary, and theologian whose Key to the Science of Theology was the first systematic presentation of LDS theology.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Julius Caesar
articles.summary: Gaius Julius Caesar (100–44 BC) was a Roman general and statesman whose military genius and political ambition transformed the Roman Republic into what became the Roman Empire — and whose career shaped the world into which Jesus Christ was born.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Alexander the Great
articles.summary: Alexander the Great (356–323 BC) was the King of Macedon whose campaigns created one of the largest empires in ancient history, spreading Greek language and culture across the world and creating the Hellenistic environment of the New Testament.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Athens
articles.summary: Athens was the cultural and intellectual heart of ancient Greece — birthplace of democracy, philosophy, drama, and the Western intellectual tradition. Home to Socrates, Plato, and the Parthenon, Athens produced ideas that still shape law, science, and thought across the Western world.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Sparta
articles.summary: Sparta was a powerful Greek city-state renowned for its extraordinary military culture and discipline, producing the finest soldiers in the ancient world and providing Athens's great rival for the leadership of Greece.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Delphi
articles.summary: Delphi was the most sacred site in the ancient Greek world — home to the Oracle of Apollo, whose pronouncements guided kings, generals, and city-states for nearly a thousand years, and whose maxims including 'Know thyself' shaped Greek culture and philosophy.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Western History
articles.summary: Western history is the story of civilizations that grew from ancient Greece and Rome, passed through Christian Europe, and produced the modern world — and the providential stage on which the Restoration of the gospel took place.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: King Arthur
articles.summary: King Arthur is the legendary British ruler whose story — with Guinevere, Lancelot, Merlin, and the Knights of the Round Table — is one of the most enduring in Western literature, rich with themes of chivalry, sacrifice, and the quest for the Holy Grail.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Vikings
articles.summary: The Vikings were Norse seafarers from Scandinavia who, between roughly 793 and 1100 AD, raided, traded, explored, and settled across an extraordinary range of the world — from Newfoundland to the Volga River — leaving a permanent mark on Western civilization.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Beowulf
articles.summary: Beowulf is the oldest surviving epic poem in the English language — a 3,182-line masterpiece of Old English poetry about the hero Beowulf's battles with the monster Grendel, Grendel's mother, and a dragon, and a profound meditation on heroism, loyalty, and mortality.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Philosophy
articles.summary: Philosophy is the disciplined study of fundamental questions about reality, knowledge, morality, and existence using reason and argument. From ancient Greece to the modern world, it has shaped every intellectual tradition in Western civilization.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Metaphysics
articles.summary: Metaphysics is the branch of philosophy that investigates the fundamental nature of reality — what exists, what kinds of things exist, and how they relate to one another.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Epistemology
articles.summary: Epistemology is the branch of philosophy that investigates the nature, sources, and limits of human knowledge.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Aesthetics
articles.summary: Aesthetics is the branch of philosophy concerned with beauty, art, and taste — asking what makes something beautiful, what art is, and whether aesthetic judgments are objective.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Ethics
articles.summary: Ethics is the branch of philosophy that investigates morality — what is right and wrong, good and bad, what we owe to each other, and how we should live.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Philosophy of Religion
articles.summary: Philosophy of religion is the philosophical examination of religious beliefs, practices, and experience — asking whether belief in God is rational and addressing the problem of evil.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Philosophy of Law
articles.summary: Philosophy of law — also called jurisprudence — asks fundamental questions about the nature, purpose, and basis of law, including the relationship between law and morality.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Theology
articles.summary: Theology is faith seeking understanding — the disciplined study of God, revelation, and religious doctrine. From classical arguments for God's existence to the distinctive doctrines of the restored gospel, theology explores what God has revealed.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
articles.summary: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is a Christian faith founded through the prophet Joseph Smith in 1830, believing in the restoration of Christ's original church, continuing revelation, and the fullness of the gospel.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Christian History
articles.summary: Christian history spans two thousand years, from the ministry of Jesus Christ to the global faith of over 2 billion believers today — including the Great Apostasy, the medieval church, the Reformation, and the Restoration.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Bible
articles.summary: The Bible is the foundational scripture of Christianity — a library of books spanning thousands of years of God's dealings with mankind. Latter-day Saints revere the King James Version as the word of God, complemented by additional scripture.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Doctrine and Covenants
articles.summary: The Doctrine and Covenants is a collection of divine revelations received primarily by Joseph Smith, addressing the restored Church directly in the modern era — covering church organization, priesthood, cosmic theology, and the afterlife.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Pearl of Great Price
articles.summary: The Pearl of Great Price is one of the four standard works of the LDS Church, containing the Book of Moses, the Book of Abraham, Joseph Smith—History, and the Articles of Faith, restoring ancient truths and clarifying LDS doctrine.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Probability Theory
articles.summary: Probability theory is the branch of mathematics that quantifies uncertainty and studies random phenomena. It underpins statistics, machine learning, physics, finance, and all modern data-driven decision-making.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Algebra
articles.summary: Algebra is the branch of mathematics that uses letters and symbols to represent numbers and quantities, allowing us to write general rules and solve equations. It is the gateway to all higher mathematics.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Trigonometry
articles.summary: Trigonometry is the branch of mathematics studying relationships between angles and sides of triangles. Essential for navigation, physics, and engineering, it provides the mathematical foundation for wave analysis and periodic phenomena.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Physics
articles.summary: Physics is the most fundamental of the natural sciences — the study of matter, energy, space, and time. From Newton's laws to Einstein's relativity and quantum mechanics, it drives every major technological revolution.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Isaac Newton
articles.summary: Sir Isaac Newton (1643–1727) was an English mathematician and physicist who formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation, co-invented calculus, and laid the foundation for classical mechanics and the scientific worldview.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Leonhard Euler
articles.summary: Leonhard Euler (1707–1783) was a Swiss mathematician who made foundational contributions to calculus, number theory, graph theory, and physics. The most prolific mathematician in history, his notation still forms the backbone of modern mathematics.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Leonardo da Vinci
articles.summary: Leonardo da Vinci (1452–1519) was an Italian Renaissance polymath — painter, scientist, engineer, and inventor. Creator of the Mona Lisa and The Last Supper, he is the supreme example of the Renaissance ideal of universal genius.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Renaissance
articles.summary: The Renaissance was a transformative cultural movement that began in 14th-century Italy and spread across Europe, marking the transition from the medieval world to the modern era through humanism, art, science, and the revival of classical learning.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Crusades
articles.summary: The Crusades were a series of religious wars (1095–1291) launched by the papacy to recover the Holy Land from Muslim control. Complex in motivation and devastating in impact, they permanently shaped Christian-Muslim relations and medieval Europe.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Reformation
articles.summary: The Protestant Reformation was a 16th-century religious revolution launched by Martin Luther that permanently split Western Christianity, reshaped European politics, and — from an LDS perspective — providentially prepared the world for the Restoration of the gospel.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: J.R.R. Tolkien
articles.summary: J.R.R. Tolkien (1892–1973) was an English author, poet, and Oxford professor whose devout Catholic faith and love of mythology gave the world Middle-earth — The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: C.S. Lewis
articles.summary: C.S. Lewis (1898–1963) was a British author and Christian apologist whose works — from Mere Christianity to The Chronicles of Narnia — have profoundly influenced millions, including many Latter-day Saints.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Getting Started with EduWiki
articles.summary: An introduction to using and navigating EduWiki.
articles.author: EduWiki Admin

articles.title: How to Create a New Article
articles.summary: Step-by-step guide to adding a new article to EduWiki using the .wmd format.
articles.author: EduWiki Admin

articles.title: WMD Format Reference
articles.summary: Complete reference for the .wmd (Wiki Markdown) format used to write EduWiki articles.
articles.author: EduWiki Admin

articles.title: Formatting Guide
articles.summary: Learn how to use headings, lists, tables, and other text formatting in EduWiki articles.
articles.author: EduWiki Admin

articles.title: Interactive Components Guide
articles.summary: Learn how to embed Desmos graphs, dropdowns, LaTeX math, and other interactive components.
articles.author: EduWiki Admin

articles.title: Quantum Mechanics
articles.summary: Quantum mechanics is the branch of physics that describes the behavior of matter and energy at atomic and subatomic scales, revealing a world of probability, wave-particle duality, and fundamental uncertainty.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Theory of Relativity
articles.summary: Einstein's theory of relativity — both special and general — revolutionized our understanding of space, time, gravity, and the universe, replacing Newton's classical mechanics for extreme speeds and massive objects.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Assembly Language
articles.summary: Assembly language is a low-level programming language that provides a direct, human-readable representation of machine code instructions, giving programmers precise control over hardware.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Linux
articles.summary: Linux is a free, open-source Unix-like operating system kernel created by Linus Torvalds in 1991. It powers the majority of servers, supercomputers, Android devices, and embedded systems worldwide.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Bash (Unix Shell)
articles.summary: Bash (Bourne Again Shell) is the default command-line shell on most Linux and macOS systems. It provides a powerful scripting language for automating tasks, managing files, and interacting with the operating system.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: C Programming Language
articles.summary: C is a general-purpose, procedural programming language created by Dennis Ritchie at Bell Labs in the early 1970s. It remains one of the most influential and widely-used languages, powering operating systems, embedded systems, and system software.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: C++ Programming Language
articles.summary: C++ is a powerful, general-purpose programming language created by Bjarne Stroustrup as an extension of C. It adds object-oriented programming and is widely used for system software, game engines, and high-performance applications.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Citations Guide
articles.summary: How to properly add and format citations and references in EduWiki articles.
articles.author: EduWiki Admin

articles.title: Love
articles.summary: Love is one of the most fundamental concepts in philosophy and theology — examined through the Greek distinctions of agape, philia, and eros, and celebrated in Christian thought as the greatest of all virtues.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Nutrition
articles.summary: Nutrition is the science of how living organisms obtain and use food for energy, growth, and health. Christian thought emphasizes care for the body as a temple of God.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Ecology
articles.summary: Ecology is the scientific study of interactions among living organisms and their environments. Christian stewardship ethics call believers to care for God's creation.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Psychology
articles.summary: Psychology is the scientific study of mind and behavior. Christian psychology integrates faith and science, viewing the human person as made in the image of God with a soul, conscience, and free will.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Geology
articles.summary: Geology is the science of the Earth — its materials, structures, processes, and history. Christians have engaged geology as a discipline that reveals the grandeur of God's creation.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Sociology
articles.summary: Sociology is the study of human society, social institutions, and collective behavior. Christian sociology examines how covenant community, moral order, and the call to build Zion shape social life.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Agriculture
articles.summary: Agriculture is the cultivation of crops and livestock for food, fiber, and fuel. Biblical and Christian traditions have always recognized farming as a sacred vocation tied to stewardship of the earth.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Formal Logic
articles.summary: Formal logic is the study of valid inference using symbolic systems. From Aristotle's syllogisms to modern mathematical logic, it has been an indispensable tool of theology and natural philosophy.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Mathematical Proofs
articles.summary: A mathematical proof is a logical argument that establishes a theorem beyond all doubt. The axiomatic method, developed by Euclid, reflects the Christian conviction that God's creation operates by rational, discoverable laws.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: United States Government
articles.summary: The government of the United States was shaped by classical Greek and Roman political philosophy, Christian natural law theory, and Enlightenment thought. Its founders drew deeply on Cicero, Aristotle, Polybius, and the English common law tradition.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Declaration of Independence
articles.summary: The Declaration of Independence (1776) proclaimed the American colonies' separation from Britain and articulated a political philosophy rooted in Christian natural law, classical republicanism, and Enlightenment thought.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: United States Constitution
articles.summary: The United States Constitution (1787) is the supreme law of the land, establishing the framework of federal government. Its design reflects classical mixed-government theory, Christian natural law, and hard-won lessons from history.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: American Revolution
articles.summary: The American Revolution (1765–1783) was a political and military struggle that gave birth to the United States. The Founders drew heavily on classical Greek and Roman thought, Christian theology, and English constitutional precedent.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: United States History
articles.summary: United States history spans from the founding of the colonial settlements through the present day. The nation's classical and Christian foundations, its experiment in republican self-government, and its providential narrative are central themes.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: American Civil War
articles.summary: The American Civil War (1861–1865) was the defining crisis of American history, fought over slavery, states' rights, and the meaning of the Union. Christian moral arguments shaped both sides, and Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address stands as one of the great theological documents of American life.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Brigham Young
articles.summary: Brigham Young (1801–1877) was the second President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the leader of the pioneer exodus to the Utah Territory, and one of the most consequential figures in nineteenth-century American religious history.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Socrates
articles.summary: Socrates (c. 470–399 BC) was an Athenian philosopher widely regarded as the founder of Western philosophy. His Socratic method of questioning — preserved in Plato's dialogues — transformed how humanity thinks about ethics, knowledge, and the good life.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Plato
articles.summary: Plato (c. 428–348 BC) was an Athenian philosopher, student of Socrates, and founder of the Academy. His Theory of Forms, political philosophy, and dialogues on the soul have shaped Western thought for two and a half millennia.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Aristotle
articles.summary: Aristotle (384–322 BC) was a Greek philosopher and polymath — student of Plato, tutor of Alexander the Great, and founder of the Lyceum. He made foundational contributions to logic, metaphysics, ethics, biology, and political philosophy.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Marcus Aurelius
articles.summary: Marcus Aurelius (AD 121–180) was Roman Emperor and Stoic philosopher whose private journal, the Meditations, is one of the most celebrated works of philosophical reflection ever written — a ruler's daily effort to live virtuously.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Stoicism
articles.summary: Stoicism is a philosophical school founded in Athens c. 300 BC that holds virtue is the only true good and that happiness depends entirely on one's own character and judgments. It includes a rich metaphysics and a significant comparison between Greek and Roman Stoics.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Cicero
articles.summary: Marcus Tullius Cicero (106–43 BC) was the greatest Roman orator, statesman, and the primary transmitter of Greek philosophy to the Latin world. His natural law theory became foundational for Christian political theology and Western jurisprudence.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: William Shakespeare
articles.summary: William Shakespeare (1564–1616) is the most celebrated writer in the English language. In 37 plays and 154 sonnets he explored the full range of human experience with a mastery of language and psychological insight that has never been surpassed.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Ancient Hebrew
articles.summary: Ancient Hebrew is the Semitic language of the Hebrew Bible and one of the oldest continuously attested literary languages in the world. It was the language of ancient Israel and Judah, and its root-and-pattern morphology gives it remarkable depth and coherence.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Dead Sea Scrolls
articles.summary: The Dead Sea Scrolls are approximately 981 ancient Jewish manuscripts discovered near Qumran (1947–1956), dating from the third century BC to the first century AD. They are the oldest known manuscripts of the Hebrew Bible and the greatest archaeological find of the twentieth century.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Faith
articles.summary: Faith is the foundational principle of action in religious life — a confident trust in God and His promises that moves people to act before they have perfect knowledge. In Latter-day Saint theology, faith in Jesus Christ is the first principle of the gospel.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Repentance
articles.summary: Repentance is the process of turning from sin toward God — a complete change of mind, heart, and conduct made possible by the Atonement of Jesus Christ. It is the second principle of the gospel and the essential response to sin for those who wish to receive God's forgiveness.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Baptism
articles.summary: Baptism is the first saving ordinance of the gospel — an outward covenant act of immersion in water that signifies the remission of sins, entrance into the Church of Jesus Christ, and commitment to follow Him. It is performed by proper priesthood authority.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Latter-day Saint Doctrine
articles.summary: Latter-day Saint doctrine is a restored form of ancient Christianity revealed through Joseph Smith, with distinctive teachings on the Godhead, the plan of salvation, priesthood authority, and eternal progression that differ significantly from traditional Christian theology.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Latter-day Saint Temples
articles.summary: Latter-day Saint temples are the most sacred buildings in the Church — dedicated houses of the Lord where members receive essential ordinances including the endowment, eternal marriage sealings, and proxy baptism for deceased ancestors.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Roman Catholic Church
articles.summary: The Roman Catholic Church is the world's largest Christian denomination with approximately 1.4 billion members. It traces its origins to Jesus and the Apostles, claims apostolic succession from Peter, and has shaped Western civilization more deeply than any other single institution.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Eastern Orthodox Churches
articles.summary: The Eastern Orthodox Church is the second-largest Christian denomination, with approximately 260 million members. Separated from Rome in 1054, it preserves a distinctive theology centered on theosis (deification) and has shaped the cultures of Greece, Russia, and the broader Eastern world.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Statistics
articles.summary: Statistics is the mathematical science of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data. It divides into descriptive statistics (summarizing data) and inferential statistics (drawing conclusions from samples), and is essential to science, economics, and policy.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Economics
articles.summary: Economics is the social science studying how individuals, businesses, and societies allocate scarce resources. It encompasses microeconomics (supply and demand, market structures) and macroeconomics (GDP, inflation, monetary policy), drawing on mathematical modeling and statistical analysis.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Silmarillion
articles.summary: J.R.R. Tolkien's posthumously published mythological history of Middle-earth, spanning the creation of the world, the war against Morgoth, and the tragic tales of the Elves â€” including Beren and LÃºthien. Saturated with Christian themes of creation, fall, and redemption.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Hobbit
articles.summary: J.R.R. Tolkien's beloved adventure story of Bilbo Baggins, who is swept off on a quest with thirteen dwarves to reclaim a mountain kingdom from the dragon Smaug. The tale that introduced Middle-earth and led to The Lord of the Rings.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Lord of the Rings
articles.summary: J.R.R. Tolkien's monumental fantasy epic following Frodo Baggins on a quest to destroy the One Ring of Power. Widely regarded as the greatest fantasy novel ever written, it is suffused with Christian themes of providence, mercy, and redemption.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: The Chronicles of Narnia
articles.summary: C.S. Lewis's seven-volume fantasy series set in the magical world of Narnia, featuring the great Lion Aslan as a figure of Christ. Written to help children (and adults) encounter Christian truth through the imagination, these books remain among the most beloved works of children's literature.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Mere Christianity
articles.summary: C.S. Lewis's landmark work of Christian apologetics, originally delivered as BBC radio broadcasts during World War II. It presents Lewis's famous argument from morality for God's existence and the Liar-Lunatic-Lord trilemma for Christ's divinity â€” one of the most influential Christian books of the twentieth century.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Music Theory
articles.summary: Music theory is the study of the language and grammar of music â€” pitch, rhythm, harmony, counterpoint, and form â€” tracing its roots from Pythagorean mathematics through medieval Church modes to the masterworks of J.S. Bach and beyond.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Art History
articles.summary: Art history surveys the visual arts from ancient Greece and Rome through the medieval cathedrals, the Renaissance masters, and into the modern era â€” tracing how each civilization expressed its deepest beliefs, values, and spiritual aspirations in enduring works of beauty.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Gardening
articles.summary: Gardening is the practice of cultivating plants for food, beauty, and spiritual renewal â€” a vocation honored in Scripture from the Garden of Eden to the present day, and one of the finest expressions of human stewardship over God's creation.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: General Conference (LDS Church)
articles.summary: General Conference is the twice-yearly worldwide gathering of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in which prophets, apostles, and other General Authorities deliver inspired messages of doctrine, counsel, and testimony â€” a living manifestation of the Restoration's claim that God continues to speak through living prophets.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Weather and Meteorology
articles.summary: Weather is the state of the atmosphere at a given time and place, driven by uneven solar heating of the Earth's surface. Meteorology â€” the science of weather â€” draws on physics, chemistry, and mathematics to understand and forecast the perpetual motion of air, moisture, and energy through the atmosphere.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Steam Engines
articles.summary: The steam engine is the invention that made the Industrial Revolution possible â€” converting the heat of burning coal into mechanical work on a scale that transformed manufacturing, transportation, and daily life across the world in the 18th and 19th centuries.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Telegrams and the Telegraph
articles.summary: The electric telegraph was the first technology to separate communication from physical transportation, allowing messages to cross continents in seconds. Invented in the 1830sâ€“1840s by Samuel Morse and others, it shrank the world, transformed commerce and warfare, and laid the groundwork for every modern communication technology.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Trades and Skilled Craftsmanship
articles.summary: The skilled trades â€” carpentry, masonry, plumbing, electrical work, welding, and dozens of others â€” are among the most essential and dignified forms of human work, honored in Scripture and celebrated through the medieval guild system that trained the craftsmen who built Western civilization.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Cars and Automotive Mechanics
articles.summary: The automobile transformed American life and gave ordinary people unprecedented freedom of movement. This article covers the mechanical fundamentals of how cars work â€” the internal combustion engine, transmission, brakes, suspension, and lubrication â€” giving readers the knowledge to understand, maintain, and repair their own vehicles.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Electricity: Physics and Electrical Work
articles.summary: Electricity is one of the most fundamental forces in nature and one of the most transformative technologies in human history. This article covers both the physics of electricity â€” charge, voltage, current, resistance, and electromagnetic induction â€” and the practical knowledge of the electrical trade.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Computer Architecture
articles.summary: Computer architecture studies how computers are organized â€” from transistors and logic gates through the ALU, CPU, memory hierarchy, and instruction set architecture â€” revealing how the astonishing capabilities of modern processors emerge from extraordinarily simple underlying operations.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Machine Learning
articles.summary: Machine learning is the branch of computer science and mathematics concerned with building systems that learn patterns from data. It draws on linear algebra, calculus, probability, and optimization to construct models capable of image recognition, language translation, and tasks once thought to require human intelligence.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Greek Philosophy
articles.summary: Greek philosophy is the foundation of Western intellectual life â€” born in ancient Greece around 600 BC, it gave the world formal logic, virtue ethics, natural law, and the great tradition of rational inquiry into reality, knowledge, and the good life that has shaped every intellectual tradition in the Western world.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Roman Philosophy
articles.summary: Roman philosophy adapted the schools of ancient Greece â€” especially Stoicism â€” for a civilization obsessed with practical virtue and public duty, producing in Cicero, Seneca, and Marcus Aurelius some of the most enduring moral writings in any language and the classical doctrine of natural law that shaped Western jurisprudence and the American founding.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Catholic Philosophy
articles.summary: Catholic philosophy is the rich intellectual tradition of the Church â€” from Augustine through Aquinas and beyond â€” that has brought Greek reason and Christian revelation into creative dialogue, insisting that faith and reason are complementary paths to truth and producing in the Scholastic movement some of the greatest philosophical and theological work in human history.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Chinese Philosophy
articles.summary: Chinese philosophy is one of the oldest and most distinctive intellectual traditions in the world, encompassing the great schools of Confucianism, Taoism, and Legalism born in the turbulent Warring States period, as well as the Chinese forms of Buddhism â€” traditions that shaped East Asian civilization as profoundly as Plato and Aristotle shaped the West.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Western Philosophy
articles.summary: Western philosophy is the great intellectual tradition stretching from ancient Greece through Rome, medieval Christendom, the Renaissance, the Enlightenment, and into the modern era â€” a twenty-five-century conversation about reality, knowledge, morality, and the good society that has been shaped at every stage by the creative tension between Greek reason and Christian faith.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Eastern Philosophy
articles.summary: Eastern philosophy encompasses the rich and diverse philosophical traditions of Asia â€” the Hindu philosophies of India, the Buddhist traditions flowering across the continent, the Confucian and Taoist schools of China, and the contemplative traditions of Japan and Korea â€” addressing the same fundamental questions as Western philosophy from strikingly different starting points.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Indian Philosophy
articles.summary: Indian philosophy is one of the oldest and deepest philosophical traditions in the world â€” stretching from the Vedas and Upanishads through the six orthodox Hindu schools, the heterodox traditions of Buddhism and Jainism, and the great medieval Vedanta debates â€” addressing questions of the self, ultimate reality, liberation, and right action with extraordinary sophistication.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: World Religions
articles.summary: The study of world religions is among the most important and humanizing of intellectual pursuits â€” a survey of how billions of human beings across history have answered the deepest questions of existence, from the Abrahamic faiths of the Middle East to the Dharmic traditions of India and the philosophical religions of East Asia.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Abrahamic Religions
articles.summary: The Abrahamic religions â€” Judaism, Christianity, and Islam â€” are the three great monotheistic faiths tracing their spiritual ancestry to the patriarch Abraham, together followed by more than half of humanity and having shaped the history, law, philosophy, art, and politics of human civilization more profoundly than any other religious tradition.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Christianity
articles.summary: Christianity is the world's largest religion â€” the faith of more than two billion people and the spiritual, moral, and intellectual foundation of Western civilization â€” centered on the person and work of Jesus Christ: his incarnation, crucifixion, bodily resurrection, and the promise of eternal life to all who trust in him.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Latter-day Saint Philosophy
articles.summary: Latter-day Saint philosophy is one of the most distinctive and original theological-philosophical systems in the modern world, introducing through Joseph Smith's Restoration a set of metaphysical and anthropological claims â€” an embodied God, eternal intelligences, the materiality of spirit, and the destiny of eternal progression â€” that challenge the basic assumptions of classical Western theology.
articles.author: EduWiki Team

articles.title: Ancient Egypt
articles.summary: Ancient Egypt is one of the greatest civilizations in human history â€” flourishing for more than three thousand years along the Nile, producing the pyramids, hieroglyphics, and a sophisticated religion â€” and holds a unique place in Christian and Jewish faith as the land of Israel's sojourn, the stage of the Exodus, and the training ground of Moses.
articles.author: EduWiki Team
